hedline.hl1: U.N.-NATO Court Setup in Kosovo Faulted

abstract.p: Joint United Nations-NATO administration of Kosovo is harshly criticized for running a justice system below international standards in report by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (S)

block.p: The joint United Nations-NATO administration of Kosovo has been harshly criticized for running a justice system below international standards.

The report by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, issued on Wednesday, said the police and military routinely held suspects without charge for longer than the legal limit of 72 hours.
The joint United Nations-NATO administration of Kosovo has been harshly criticized for running a justice system below international standards.

The report by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, issued on Wednesday, said the police and military routinely held suspects without charge for longer than the legal limit of 72 hours.
Military commanders admit that they hold suspects for up to 30 days, but argue that to do so is preferable to letting Albanians and Serbs carry out murderous revenge attacks.

Judges and prosecutors have recently been imported from other countries to hear cases and train their local counterparts. For years, all Albanians were barred from civil service, and many of the province's Serbian civil servants fled when the Yugoslav Army left Kosovo.

Since then, the United Nations has been struggling to create a new police and court system. Many people are arrested each day for carrying weapons. Grenade and rocket attacks and shootings are not uncommon, and finding and protecting witnesses is often difficult, law enforcement officials say.
